Baldsin, Iate pastor of the 2d Baptist Chuych Boston-"f feel free to say that in my esti- nation it deservedly ranks among ables and best Commentaries All the leading doctrines of Chris tanity as professed and maintained by many Of the most eminent Reformers are in my judgment very hap pily illustrated and enforced" 'r

 Rep Dr.. Dana.-" Dr. Scott's Commentary, has merited and obtained distinguished popularity. The spirit which pervades the work is excellent. 1t is the meek, aectionate healing yet faithful, spirit of the Gospel.

 Beside tke abope MANY OTHERS of the most in- fentnI dnORgt the Clergy hQre recommended tis ScOk he too1ring ertractS hO'CeCer, from Mr. EnneTs0RS letter aoiH point out tue adUantGges peculiar to the OC TAVO edition. s.

 Reu Joseph Emerson, Author Of the EcdngelicdLt Pri,ner-" Six editions of this great work have been published in this country-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of ali these six editions, and am decidedly of opinion that most people would greatly prefer ARMSTRONGS EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, he volumes not ,nearly so large the quarto editions but the paper is finer and whter the execution handsomer the print to appearance nearly as large; and it be turned to the light with much less inconvenience, it may perhaps be read with equal and pleasure It has the advantage of De- ing cheaper, less cumbersome and more elegant.

 "ARMSTRONG's EDITION, therefore, is the one which I can most highly recommend for the use of families. Itis peculiarly calculated to supersede the of large Bble and in two respects it will better purpose merely for reading the scrip lures, as it is less cumbersome, and may be read by several persons at the same time."

 2. A disposition to mullIp lhe circe'na.anee. which fprnish the occasions and opportnii.es lor drek,ng may justly create alnfm thai tlle habt q begun. When yUu nhd occasions tor drinking 10 all the sariaons ot fhe weather because it hot or 60 cold-so wet or co dry-and in all the different states of the system wheay you vigorous, that you need pot ure, and when iired that your vgor may be restored, you have Approached near that state ofntemperanee in which YOU will drink in a states of the weather, and condl- lions of the body, and will drink with these prcteXts, and drink without them whenever their frequency may not suffice. In kemanner if on your farm, orInyOur stone workshop, or on board your vessa you love to multiply the catchesand occasions of drinking, m the forms of treats for new comers-for misakesiOr new articles of dressor furniture-unt m some Pia- scarcelyswear an article of dress, or re- ccive of equipage furniture which has n0tbeen "wet' you may rely it that all these usages, and ruIes and laws are devices to gratify an nordnate and dangerous love of strong drink and though the master of the shop should not himself come down to such little measures, yet fine permits things to be done, if he hears, and sees, andsmies and sometimes sips little of the forfeited beverage his heart IS m the thing, and he is under the influence of dangerous love of that hilarity which is produced by strong drink. ..,<t ,

 3. Whoever finds the desire of drinking ardent spirits returning daily at stated tmes is warned to deny himself instantly, if he intends to escape conlr- med intemperance.

 It is infllibe evidence that you have already done violence to natnre-that theundermnng process be. gun--that the overworked organ begins to flag, and 

 ifindulged, will become more deep toned, and lmpor- tlnate, and irresistible, until the power of sedenaI is gone, and you are ruined man. It IS the vortex begun, which, if not checked, becomes more capa- cous and deep, and loud, until the interests of time and eternity are enguifed.

 Itis here then--beside this commencing vortex that would take my stand to warn of the needless navigator from destruction. To all who do but heave in sight and with voice that should rise above the winds and waves, I would cry" stand off!!!'- spread the saiI ply the oar, for death is here-and could command the elements--the backness ot darkness should gather this gateway to hell-- and loud thunders should utter their voces-and lurid fires should blaze and the groans of unearhiy voices should be heard-inspiring consternation and Ight m ali wIo came near. For this is the parting point be- tween those who forsake danger and hide themselves, and the foolish who pass and are punished. lie

 who escapes this periodical thirst of times and sea- sons, will not be a drunkard, as he who comes within the reach of this powerful attraction will be sure to perish It may not be certain that every one will be- come sot; but it is certain that every one will enee- be his body, generate disease and shorten his days It may be certain that every will sacrifice his reputation, squander his property and die in the alms-house buts certain that large proportion will poverty and infamy, of those who yield daily the periodical appetite for ardent spirits Here IS the stopping place, and though beyond 1t men may struggle and retard and modify their progress, none, comparatively who go by it, will return again to pur- ty and enjoyment, and the sweets of temperate ber- ty. The servant has become the master, and, with rod of iron and whip of scorpions, he will torment before their time, the candidates for misery in future state.

and who had not committed theInsevcs on eicr sde. Ae soon as the missionaries could assrmhla from the dirrcnt islands they met aa llonoFuru. They sent note. requesting that committee of m equal number from both bodies might be appointed, to arrange the manner in which the interview should be conducted. This proposal rejected by the British Consul, who seemed lo act as leader of the opposition; and who named time and place at which he and his friends would expect meet the missionaries in body. In this manner they did meet, Capt. Jones and his oiii cers with oft chiefs of the island, being pres cnt; also, many foreigners spectators, who did not join in the accusations brought.

 The missionaries required specific charges in wTi- ting with the of witnesses: but this was refu- sed They were told that they must vindicate them selves without such spec6catoni and that their chal- lege imported that they would take thisground. Capt Jones called for the reading of the challenge; and the necessity of specifying the charges was apparent to all. Still, no charges were made, or atcmpted.- The foreigners then said the ascendancy of the mis- sionares the natives such that no one dared give his testimony. The missionaries replied, we do want Le gGk evidence: but any evidence that would have influence on candid and judicious men. This too refused; and nothing was offered, but some violent and scurrous yuperation of the missionaries And thus ended the interview.

 Capt. Jones' subsequent conversation sa'd the ef- feet would be exat the the character and extend the influence of the missionaries, in the most decisive and efficient manner. He also c0lfGHdTfty addressed a letter to hem which is decidedly in their favor. It IS known that any of his officers have expressed any different opinion and there is every reason to believe that this arbitration has rolled back the tide o caum- ny and that its authors have duraby injured themselves alone.

Letter to of the Editors of the Boston Recorder

 dated, Kailua, Hascaii, No0. 20, 1896.

 have little say of any material interest which IS not already communicated to the Board: but there IS one event which transpircd about three months snce which occasioned much observation among this peo- pie, and the time, matter ot considerable lh- teres alude to an attempt recently made m liam akua the northern district of this Island, to revve the worship of Peie, the fabled goddess of Voca- t .A.

 Though we had supposed that organism was entire- y extinct, being often assured by the natives tnatsuch was the case yet it appears by the sequel that wo- of distinction ill Hamakua, by name Wanneo-

 au former priestess of the Volcanic Deity, still ad- hered to her former beief and to the secret obsery ance ofher worship. At the time that passed thro the District where she dwells, in December of last year, the natives informed me of this woman and sad also that she had abandoned her form of worship ltwas my purpose have visited her my way, but as my path lay through the upper route passed the place of her residence ere was aware. however left young man, who had been of our scholars, to commence a school in that neighborhood, and then pursued my route. This circumstance excited her apprehensions that she might lose Aer influence the minds of the people in that region, and aro- sed her opposition From that time she began to pre- dict the coming wrath of Pele to with her fire the land aud it's inhabitants, in particular all who adhered to the instructions of the new teachers In the month of July last she determined to make last desperate effort and put her predictions to the tes

 She assembled the people to general sacrlhce, and having collected together several small stone images

 

 drppings of the liquid p caves, and the votaes of Pee sacred the goddess these she folded up in tapa, and placed them by the altar She then sacrificed hogs, fowls, &c and laid them upon the altar together with taro, bananas. and other cscu- lent vegetables, as an offering to her deity. Having thus prepared the sacrifice she began her vocferous prayers while others uniting with her encouraged her to persevere crying out necessarily "Mana ka Pele, mana ka ele,"--(thc Pele is mighty, the Pole is

 ghty and assured her that she would presently arr rive with her fires to consume the sacrifice and over run the and Thus they continued the whole day un- til evening, "but there was neither voice. nor any an swcr, nor any thing thatregarded" At evening some fire was secretly conveyed along with combustibles un- der inc tapa that covered the idols, which presently began to baze The cry was immediately raised that Pcle had come, upon which the spectators were ai- frighted and run away in all haste to escape But Pa kua, the teacher above mentioned, called them back telling them it was only ahi aoi, common re) con- ceaed there for the purpose to deceive them; and to convince them of the fact, he uncovered the images and extingushed it. The people, indignant at the imposition and their foolish fears caught up the images and scattered them abroad, did they cease until they had demolished the altar, together with all the apparatus of their idolatry. va ~

 This account was given me shortly after by Gov. Adams, and in few weeks had the satisfaction to witness her arrival in this place, to receive instruction in the doctrines and duties of Christianity She resi- .ded here about two months, during which time she called on frequently, accompanied by her husband. The Gov. assigned them teacher and they commen-. ced in to attend to instruction. Atchurch her attention was uniformly fixed upon the preacher, and we have pleasing hopes that many serious and lasting impressions have fastened upon her mind. She de- cared her fnl conviction of the alacy of her former belief, but seemed evidently aversc to talk upon the subject ofher last desperate attempt revive the old abolished pagan rites May every attempt of satan to destroy the souls of men prove equally abortve, and may the final result m every case be equally overruled, to the praise aud the glory of Divine grace. y3.a s

 With many salutatons, remain, dear Sir, yours in the bonds of the gospel,

NOTICE.

In the Recorder of June 22d, we re-pubished an Appeal which the Missionaries at the Sandwich Isl. ands made on the spot in October las in which the, challenged an investigation of their conduct. This was very proper course, considering how much and how long they had sufFered and how their abors had been impeded, by the reproach of foreigners, both English and American. We learn from the PhiladeI- phia Christian Advocate that this challenge was ac- cepted and has led to an important result The ac- count is derived from Mr. Loomis, who has returned to this country; and we hasten give the substance though the particulars must be deferred.

 This challenge was accepted, and dacorrespondence ersued between the foreigners andthe missionaries.

 The oFeigners proposed and the Missionaries agreed that the investigation should be held before Capt. Jones and his officers of the U. s. Ship of war Pea COck, who had been but short time at the islands,

 Present F. WOLCOTT, Esq. Judge
NOTICE.

No article of Houshold Manufactures will be enti- tied to premium. unless manufactured entirely within the county.

 To entitle himself to premiums for Agricultural Productions, the person claiming must state in wri- ting, and prove to the satisfaction of the Awarding Committee, the quantity of land, and the amount ot the product ito be ascertained by measure, and must also state n writing the nature kind of soil-the previous situation of the land-how tilledthe kind and quality of manure, and how and when appied-how the seed was applied, and how, and when sown and the quantity per acre.

 The claims for premiums under this article must be entered with the Treasurer, MIR. LEONARD Coop WIN before the 9th day of October next but the evidence of actual product lexcept ax which will be Wheat the 1st day of January l829l will be admit ted at any time previous to the st day of January next

 Persons intending to offer Domestic Animals, or HOushold manufacures,mus give notice to the Treas urer on or before the 9th day of October next, re- qucsting an entry to be made of such notice. No premiu;u will be awarded upon any article with. out competition, unless such article shall be, in the pinion of the Awarding Committee, highly merito- rious.

 No Animal or article of Houshold Manufacture, which shall have obtained premium at previous hbition, wil under the same denomination be enti- tied to a second premium.

 statement of the quantity and quality of Milk gv- en by, and of the butter made from, the Mich Cows entered for premiums crediby attested will be requi- red ny the Awarding Committe.

 The examination of Domestic Animals and Hous- hold Manufactures will commence near the Court House, at 9 A. M.

 No person but member 1.-the Society, can be en- titled to premium except on Hearth Rugs, Bonnets, Stockings and other articles of Domestic Manuiac- lures highly meritorious.

 All premiums not called for within three months af. ter awarded, will be forfeited to the Society, UTAH persons in arrears to the Society, are re- quested to forward the amount to the Treasurer. T An GRAFTON will be delivered on the oc- casion. .

Family Bible, crninonsly calcuialed so promote tho cause of truth and peg h seema srarcely posslblo for me read daily the Notes and Observations with out becoming wiser and better man."

 Reu. Asa Eaoa, paStOr ef Chria Ch.rch, Bosloa. -" It is a TREASURE WHICH EVERY FAMILY OUGHT TO POSSESS. For the success of your undertaking you have my best wishes and fervent prayers"

 Rev. Dr. JoshuG Bafes President ef Afiddlebavy Coiegs.-" Sir, am pleased with your proposals for publishing Scot's Family Bible, and sincerely wish you success in your undertaking. have donbt that twill be well patronized by the religious public"

 Rep. Daniel Ehavp pastor Of the 3d Baptist ChMch, BOSton" The more it isread by pious Christians, the extensive will be its circulation"

 Reu. Dr.. Baldsin, Iate pastor of the 2d Baptist Chuych Boston-"f feel free to say that in my esti- nation it deservedly ranks among ables and best Commentaries All the leading doctrines of Chris tanity as professed and maintained by many Of the most eminent Reformers are in my judgment very hap pily illustrated and enforced" 'r

 Rep Dr.. Dana.-" Dr. Scott's Commentary, has merited and obtained distinguished popularity. The spirit which pervades the work is excellent. 1t is the meek, aectionate healing yet faithful, spirit of the Gospel.

 Beside tke abope MANY OTHERS of the most in- fentnI dnORgt the Clergy hQre recommended tis ScOk he too1ring ertractS hO'CeCer, from Mr. EnneTs0RS letter aoiH point out tue adUantGges peculiar to the OC TAVO edition. s.

 Reu Joseph Emerson, Author Of the EcdngelicdLt Pri,ner-" Six editions of this great work have been published in this country-I have had considerable opportunity to examine and compare specimens of ali these six editions, and am decidedly of opinion that most people would greatly prefer ARMSTRONGS EDITION, now publishing in Boston. As the fold is octave, he volumes not ,nearly so large the quarto editions but the paper is finer and whter the execution handsomer the print to appearance nearly as large; and it be turned to the light with much less inconvenience, it may perhaps be read with equal and pleasure It has the advantage of De- ing cheaper, less cumbersome and more elegant.

 "ARMSTRONG's EDITION, therefore, is the one which I can most highly recommend for the use of families. Itis peculiarly calculated to supersede the of large Bble and in two respects it will better purpose merely for reading the scrip lures, as it is less cumbersome, and may be read by several persons at the same time."

Present F. WOLCOTT, Esq. Judge.

full articles.headline: SIGNS or INTEMrERANcE.
full articles.article:
Fros Dr. btechcr's SfrmeRs cn 1Hfssspsfasce.

 2. A disposition to mullIp lhe circe'na.anee. which fprnish the occasions and opportnii.es lor drek,ng may justly create alnfm thai tlle habt q begun. When yUu nhd occasions tor drinking 10 all the sariaons ot fhe weather because it hot or 60 cold-so wet or co dry-and in all the different states of the system wheay you vigorous, that you need pot ure, and when iired that your vgor may be restored, you have Approached near that state ofntemperanee in which YOU will drink in a states of the weather, and condl- lions of the body, and will drink with these prcteXts, and drink without them whenever their frequency may not suffice. In kemanner if on your farm, orInyOur stone workshop, or on board your vessa you love to multiply the catchesand occasions of drinking, m the forms of treats for new comers-for misakesiOr new articles of dressor furniture-unt m some Pia- scarcelyswear an article of dress, or re- ccive of equipage furniture which has n0tbeen "wet' you may rely it that all these usages, and ruIes and laws are devices to gratify an nordnate and dangerous love of strong drink and though the master of the shop should not himself come down to such little measures, yet fine permits things to be done, if he hears, and sees, andsmies and sometimes sips little of the forfeited beverage his heart IS m the thing, and he is under the influence of dangerous love of that hilarity which is produced by strong drink. ..,<t ,

 3. Whoever finds the desire of drinking ardent spirits returning daily at stated tmes is warned to deny himself instantly, if he intends to escape conlr- med intemperance.

 It is infllibe evidence that you have already done violence to natnre-that theundermnng process be. gun--that the overworked organ begins to flag, and 

 ifindulged, will become more deep toned, and lmpor- tlnate, and irresistible, until the power of sedenaI is gone, and you are ruined man. It IS the vortex begun, which, if not checked, becomes more capa- cous and deep, and loud, until the interests of time and eternity are enguifed.

 Itis here then--beside this commencing vortex that would take my stand to warn of the needless navigator from destruction. To all who do but heave in sight and with voice that should rise above the winds and waves, I would cry" stand off!!!'- spread the saiI ply the oar, for death is here-and could command the elements--the backness ot darkness should gather this gateway to hell-- and loud thunders should utter their voces-and lurid fires should blaze and the groans of unearhiy voices should be heard-inspiring consternation and Ight m ali wIo came near. For this is the parting point be- tween those who forsake danger and hide themselves, and the foolish who pass and are punished. lie

 who escapes this periodical thirst of times and sea- sons, will not be a drunkard, as he who comes within the reach of this powerful attraction will be sure to perish It may not be certain that every one will be- come sot; but it is certain that every one will enee- be his body, generate disease and shorten his days It may be certain that every will sacrifice his reputation, squander his property and die in the alms-house buts certain that large proportion will poverty and infamy, of those who yield daily the periodical appetite for ardent spirits Here IS the stopping place, and though beyond 1t men may struggle and retard and modify their progress, none, comparatively who go by it, will return again to pur- ty and enjoyment, and the sweets of temperate ber- ty. The servant has become the master, and, with rod of iron and whip of scorpions, he will torment before their time, the candidates for misery in future state.

and who had not committed theInsevcs on eicr sde. Ae soon as the missionaries could assrmhla from the dirrcnt islands they met aa llonoFuru. They sent note. requesting that committee of m equal number from both bodies might be appointed, to arrange the manner in which the interview should be conducted. This proposal rejected by the British Consul, who seemed lo act as leader of the opposition; and who named time and place at which he and his friends would expect meet the missionaries in body. In this manner they did meet, Capt. Jones and his oiii cers with oft chiefs of the island, being pres cnt; also, many foreigners spectators, who did not join in the accusations brought.

 The missionaries required specific charges in wTi- ting with the of witnesses: but this was refu- sed They were told that they must vindicate them selves without such spec6catoni and that their chal- lege imported that they would take thisground. Capt Jones called for the reading of the challenge; and the necessity of specifying the charges was apparent to all. Still, no charges were made, or atcmpted.- The foreigners then said the ascendancy of the mis- sionares the natives such that no one dared give his testimony. The missionaries replied, we do want Le gGk evidence: but any evidence that would have influence on candid and judicious men. This too refused; and nothing was offered, but some violent and scurrous yuperation of the missionaries And thus ended the interview.

 Capt. Jones' subsequent conversation sa'd the ef- feet would be exat the the character and extend the influence of the missionaries, in the most decisive and efficient manner. He also c0lfGHdTfty addressed a letter to hem which is decidedly in their favor. It IS known that any of his officers have expressed any different opinion and there is every reason to believe that this arbitration has rolled back the tide o caum- ny and that its authors have duraby injured themselves alone.

M. and arrives at Pough- keepse in time to take the StcamBoat for New. or or Albany. Passengers in this line will arrive in AL bany the morning after leaving Lhchfed in time to take the morning stages for the west.

 The proprietors of this line having provided good coaches and horses and careful drivers, and reduced the fare, respectfully solicit share of public patron age. ...s. a.

full articles.headline: SANDWICH ISLANDS.
full articles.article:
Letter to of the Editors of the Boston Recorder

 dated, Kailua, Hascaii, No0. 20, 1896.

 have little say of any material interest which IS not already communicated to the Board: but there IS one event which transpircd about three months snce which occasioned much observation among this peo- pie, and the time, matter ot considerable lh- teres alude to an attempt recently made m liam akua the northern district of this Island, to revve the worship of Peie, the fabled goddess of Voca- t .A.

 Though we had supposed that organism was entire- y extinct, being often assured by the natives tnatsuch was the case yet it appears by the sequel that wo- of distinction ill Hamakua, by name Wanneo-

 au former priestess of the Volcanic Deity, still ad- hered to her former beief and to the secret obsery ance ofher worship. At the time that passed thro the District where she dwells, in December of last year, the natives informed me of this woman and sad also that she had abandoned her form of worship ltwas my purpose have visited her my way, but as my path lay through the upper route passed the place of her residence ere was aware. however left young man, who had been of our scholars, to commence a school in that neighborhood, and then pursued my route. This circumstance excited her apprehensions that she might lose Aer influence the minds of the people in that region, and aro- sed her opposition From that time she began to pre- dict the coming wrath of Pele to with her fire the land aud it's inhabitants, in particular all who adhered to the instructions of the new teachers In the month of July last she determined to make last desperate effort and put her predictions to the tes

 She assembled the people to general sacrlhce, and having collected together several small stone images

 

 drppings of the liquid p caves, and the votaes of Pee sacred the goddess these she folded up in tapa, and placed them by the altar She then sacrificed hogs, fowls, &c and laid them upon the altar together with taro, bananas. and other cscu- lent vegetables, as an offering to her deity. Having thus prepared the sacrifice she began her vocferous prayers while others uniting with her encouraged her to persevere crying out necessarily "Mana ka Pele, mana ka ele,"--(thc Pele is mighty, the Pole is

 ghty and assured her that she would presently arr rive with her fires to consume the sacrifice and over run the and Thus they continued the whole day un- til evening, "but there was neither voice. nor any an swcr, nor any thing thatregarded" At evening some fire was secretly conveyed along with combustibles un- der inc tapa that covered the idols, which presently began to baze The cry was immediately raised that Pcle had come, upon which the spectators were ai- frighted and run away in all haste to escape But Pa kua, the teacher above mentioned, called them back telling them it was only ahi aoi, common re) con- ceaed there for the purpose to deceive them; and to convince them of the fact, he uncovered the images and extingushed it. The people, indignant at the imposition and their foolish fears caught up the images and scattered them abroad, did they cease until they had demolished the altar, together with all the apparatus of their idolatry. va ~

 This account was given me shortly after by Gov. Adams, and in few weeks had the satisfaction to witness her arrival in this place, to receive instruction in the doctrines and duties of Christianity She resi- .ded here about two months, during which time she called on frequently, accompanied by her husband. The Gov. assigned them teacher and they commen-. ced in to attend to instruction. Atchurch her attention was uniformly fixed upon the preacher, and we have pleasing hopes that many serious and lasting impressions have fastened upon her mind. She de- cared her fnl conviction of the alacy of her former belief, but seemed evidently aversc to talk upon the subject ofher last desperate attempt revive the old abolished pagan rites May every attempt of satan to destroy the souls of men prove equally abortve, and may the final result m every case be equally overruled, to the praise aud the glory of Divine grace. y3.a s

 With many salutatons, remain, dear Sir, yours in the bonds of the gospel,

The work IS comprised in six volumes, royal octave and well bound and lettered, it will be sold as cheap, in proportion the size of the pages as the publications of the American Tract Society are sold.

 "EVERY FOURTH SET GRATIS! That is, any person who takes three sets in sheep binding and pays for them the sum of $72, shall be entitled to set gratis; if the same sum of S72 is divided equally on all the four sets, it will reduce the amount payable for each of the four sets to $18 instead of M being discount of 25 per cent from the retail price, discount is made in the propor- tioa on calf binding and on ANY NUMBER OF COPIES, abope jour, ho,ceUer Iarge." GJ The price at the LITCHFIELD BOOK STORE is $2l per single set, and SIS per set where four or more are taken in company.

 "The work contains the Old and New Testaments with copious Marginal References also valuable Notes explanatory of the Sculptures and, lastly, the Practi cal Observations. The work is SO generally known to all who are acquainted with the publications of the present day. that 1t is deemed unnecessary enlarge upon its contents"

 The first edition of this work, tthe constant and n- creasng sale of which proves the high esteem in which t is deservedy hed,} begun in l78s and published in London Tn numbers consisted of 1000 copies; the second in l805 OO0 the third in 18l0 of OOO the fourth in lSl2 of ,0O0; and the edition is ae,v- 0te the largest work submitted to that process Besides these eight other editions, consisting, ato- getner cf 25,25O copies were printed in the United Recorder.

M.; Tuesday, Thursday and Staturday by Watertown, Waterbury, Saiem-bridge, and Wood bridge arrives at N. Haven at r. M; and returns from N Haven in the same order. .....

 Leaves Litchfeld for Hartford, Tuesdays, Thurs days and Saturdays at o'clock in the morning thro' Harwaton, Burlington, Pennington and West-Hart- ford, and arrives in Hartford at o'clock F. M. Re- turns from Hartford Mondays, Wednesdays and 'Fri- days at 8 o'clock in the morning

 LITCHFIELD AND NORWALK.

 Leaves Litchfeld for New Milford, Danbury and Norwalk every Friday afternoon on arrival of the Stage from Hartford, through Bradleys-Ville, New Preston New Milford, Brookfeld Danbury, Reading, and Wilton, and arrives at Norwak on Saturday at 12 o'clock at noon. Returns from Norwalk Sundays, arrives at Ltchfeld Monday afternoon.

 This Line intersects the Steamboat at Norwalk and arrives in N. York same night.

full articles.headline:
From the Boston Recorder

SANDWICH IsLANDs-TME TRIAL
full articles.article:
In the Recorder of June 22d, we re-pubished an Appeal which the Missionaries at the Sandwich Isl. ands made on the spot in October las in which the, challenged an investigation of their conduct. This was very proper course, considering how much and how long they had sufFered and how their abors had been impeded, by the reproach of foreigners, both English and American. We learn from the PhiladeI- phia Christian Advocate that this challenge was ac- cepted and has led to an important result The ac- count is derived from Mr. Loomis, who has returned to this country; and we hasten give the substance though the particulars must be deferred.

 This challenge was accepted, and dacorrespondence ersued between the foreigners andthe missionaries.

 The oFeigners proposed and the Missionaries agreed that the investigation should be held before Capt. Jones and his officers of the U. s. Ship of war Pea COck, who had been but short time at the islands,

full articles.headline: NOTICE.
full articles.article:
At a Court of Probate holden at Litchfeld, within and for the District of Litchfeld, July 2d, 1897.

 Present F. WOLCOTT, Esq. Judge

No article of Houshold Manufactures will be enti- tied to premium. unless manufactured entirely within the county.

 To entitle himself to premiums for Agricultural Productions, the person claiming must state in wri- ting, and prove to the satisfaction of the Awarding Committee, the quantity of land, and the amount ot the product ito be ascertained by measure, and must also state n writing the nature kind of soil-the previous situation of the land-how tilledthe kind and quality of manure, and how and when appied-how the seed was applied, and how, and when sown and the quantity per acre.

 The claims for premiums under this article must be entered with the Treasurer, MIR. LEONARD Coop WIN before the 9th day of October next but the evidence of actual product lexcept ax which will be Wheat the 1st day of January l829l will be admit ted at any time previous to the st day of January next

 Persons intending to offer Domestic Animals, or HOushold manufacures,mus give notice to the Treas urer on or before the 9th day of October next, re- qucsting an entry to be made of such notice. No premiu;u will be awarded upon any article with. out competition, unless such article shall be, in the pinion of the Awarding Committee, highly merito- rious.

 No Animal or article of Houshold Manufacture, which shall have obtained premium at previous hbition, wil under the same denomination be enti- tied to a second premium.

 statement of the quantity and quality of Milk gv- en by, and of the butter made from, the Mich Cows entered for premiums crediby attested will be requi- red ny the Awarding Committe.

 The examination of Domestic Animals and Hous- hold Manufactures will commence near the Court House, at 9 A. M.

 No person but member 1.-the Society, can be en- titled to premium except on Hearth Rugs, Bonnets, Stockings and other articles of Domestic Manuiac- lures highly meritorious.

 All premiums not called for within three months af. ter awarded, will be forfeited to the Society, UTAH persons in arrears to the Society, are re- quested to forward the amount to the Treasurer. T An GRAFTON will be delivered on the oc- casion. .

 Per order, s. P. BOLLES, Rec. Sec.

 LITCHFIELD, JUNE 2l, 1927.
